group_1.narration: <Dolma's Side>
How long has it been since that day…?
Three days after my failed suicide attempt,@I learned of Heruka's execution.

group_1.textCenter: Why do we live in a world where people@like me survive while Heruka dies?

group_1.textLeft: Ah, I see… That's what this is about.@It's revenge.
To fight those bastards who took Heruka@from us and satisfy our resentment!
…I can't forgive them. They all keep talking@about Heruka being evil and wicked.
Heruka's name will doubtlessly go down@in history as a word for villainy.
To think that's all that will be left of her…

group_1.textRight: Then you ought to inscribe the truth, Dolma.
In truth…we have something akin to a book@of prophecy.
We came to your nunnery because@of what it said about Heruka,
but her name was never actually mentioned…
Every reference to her was under the word@"Rakshasi."
I'd been wondering why, but now I've finally@come to an answer.
It means…different interpretations@of the same idea can be born.
…into the word for the one who saved Tibet.

group_1.textLeft: …Is that what you want me to do?

group_1.textRight: Well, perhaps our purpose in coming here@was to tell you this.

group_1.textLeft: But if there's any meaning to me being able@to speak Mongolian,
then it must be so I can tell the real truth…@At least, I guess.

group_1.narration: After that, it looks like Rabi and her friends@departed from Tibet for a distant land.
As with me, the head priest arranged@things so they wouldn't be punished…@but the Mongols had their doubts about them.@Given the chance to escape, they had to take it.
"...Even so, we're glad we could come here@and spend time with Heruka."
Those were Rabi's parting words.
The head priest said the Mongols were@creating a new Mongolian writing system@by making slight adaptations@from the Tibetan script.

Our teachings have spread to Mongolia@and many of the scriptures need translation,@but since the Mongolian script was foreign,@it couldn't convey our ideas correctly.@A new shared writing system must be made.
Apparently, my role is to help spread@this new script to Mongolia.

group_1.textRight: …We know you despise us, but I can't think@of anyone more qualified…

group_1.textLeft: I don't hate you.@You protected me, remember?

group_1.narration: Ever since then, I've been helping expand@the new script invented by the temples@while collecting feedback from users.

group_1.textLeft: The improvement plans are nearly complete.@The day of official adoption will soon be here.
She left to work on composing a new inscription.

group_1.textRight: She writes in her spare time, huh…?@Do you know what it's about?

group_1.textLeft: Dolma told me that a long time ago,@she met the Savior.
…And so she's writing the story@of her memories.

group_1.narration: I've erected inscriptions all across Mongolia@where I continue to write the truth.
I have to be indirect about things@to get them past the officials@so they don't kick up a fuss.
But even so, I really love the way it starts.
"Underneath the earth lies the Rakshasi."

group_1.textCenter: …It's a lot of work to build things like this here,@but I'll keep going.
Since I'm here, I might as well take it all in.

group_1.narration: The day will come when people find@the true record of Heruka here.
I believe that.@Yes… I'll never give up hope.@And that's because…
Those blue flowers I saw with Heruka,@during the last time we were together…@They're still in bloom to this day.
Even just standing here,@I feel like Heruka is with me…
Yes…@It's like I'm looking at these flowers@with Heruka again…
…Hey, Heruka.@You saved us all.
The nunnery is business as usual.@Remember Deki?@She's the Rector now.
The town is as lively as always.@Everything you wanted to protect is still there.
Yes, your feelings, too…
I won't let despair stop me.@I'll overcome it, even if I have to do it alone.@I'm not afraid of the night anymore.
I'll do everything I can@to keep Heruka's record…@No, to keep OUR record,@alive in this world…
…to ensure that the whole world@knows that we were never defeated,@and we laughed to the very, very end.
